you have exlolained (and showed) how a separated flow works, that is a stalled wing.

I think this is a common misconception.  You may have noticed at take-off leading-edge slats are extended downwards.  This causes a situation where the air is unable to get out of the way quickly enough (at take-off speed) so it gets bounced upwards.  It soon comes back down again however with the weight of the atmosphere pushing down on it.  This has the effect of creating a vacuum along the top of the wing,  otherwise known as a 'shock wave'. Vacuums go where vacuums belong,  to the top of the atmosphere taking the plane with them.  At higher speeds the air can't keep up with the aircraft and creates drag so designers angle the wing back into the dragging shock wave cancelling much of the drag out.  By the 'sweep angle ' you can estimate the operational speed of a plane often.  When it crosses the sound barrier the bang is caused by the explosive collapse of the shock wave.  I've seen these shock waves above aircraft wings when condensation formed along them.  The wing described in the video would tend to pull the plane down in upside-down mode.

This is the physics of how planes fly. Assume a wing is flying through the air at a constant horizontal velocity in stationary air.

The curves in the streamlines diagram around an airfoil indicate that there are four main acceleration zones.

1.There is a compression accelerating zone even ahead and on and above the upper front part of the leading edge.
2. There is a suction accelerating zone after location (1) existing along the upper surface to the trailing edge.
3. There is a suction accelerating zone just behind the lower part of the leading edge.
4. There is a compression accelerating zone existing from location (3) going all the way under the lower surface to the trailing edge.

All these four zones are easier seen on a highly cambered airfoil section. The practical meaning of these pressure suction zones could be interpreted as follows. Let us use the diagram shown at 0:53. Assume the mass of a stationary air/ fluid particle consists of a fat man holding an opened umbrella to create a piston effect.


One fat stationary man, with an opened umbrella, located above the mean horizontal line, is hit ( compressed) and pushed and vectored up and accelerated up through action ( 1) and the oncoming upper leading edge angle will vector and shoot the man up, but with him holding the open umbrella, a partial vacuum will be created behind the man, between the area of the umbrella and the surface of the wing, and so this partial vacuum will pull down the man and suck up the wing as it passes under the fat man to dump him later on over the trailing edge using Action (2)


A second fat stationary man, with an opened umbrella, located below the mean horizontal line, is sucked up by action ( 3), and then the compression zone through action ( 4) will push the fat man down and the reaction would be a push up on the undersurface of the wing, to later dumping the second fat man behind the trailing edge to join the first fat man being dumped from the upper surface behind the trailing edge. Both fat men can be regarded as having flown up and down in a quasi vertical manner as the wing slid horizontally. Note that in real flying action, the two fat men with the umbrellas are operated upon by the actions indicated in zones 1. 2. 3. 4. and from the physical logic and time sequence of the actions/ reactions in these four zones, the upper-fat man will result in having a higher backward horizontal velocity than the lower fat man, due to the fact that one man was moving into an upper vectored suction zone and the other moving in an undersurface vectored compression zone, before both of them were dumped behind the trailing edge, not exactly vertically in actual wing behavior. It is the summations of these quasi vertical accelerations of lumps/masses of fluid be it air or water, that make an air wing and a water foil fly., where the vertical accelerations contribute to lift and the horizontal acceleration causes drag.


These acceleration actions and dumpings are repeated on the massed fluid particles existing ahead of and distributed
within a fairly large voluminous zone around the wing.

I got one (or a couple) for you all. Please help me!

The earth spins at a 1000 mph only at the equator because there the circumference is 24000 miles(:24hr). The circumference gets less and less untill it's basically 0 at either pole. A helicopter hovering at the equator would make a 24000 mile loop in a day while it would not make any kind of movement while hovering above the pole except off course the motions of flying around the sun and simultaneously around a black hole at speeds i cannot imagine. Just ignore these last 2 motions for convenience since they are constant and we don't notice them anyway.

U could say it would have to automatically make a pirouette above the pole though because if it doesn't automatically align to the earth the world would actually spin beneath the helicopter :P And yes I understand that flying an actual helicopter requires constant manual adjustment. This thought experiment exists on a world without wind with a perfectly balanced state of the art helicopter with unlimited fuel.

Say this helicopter were to fly from the equator straight over the pole to the other side of the planet . At take off it is going 1000 mph sideways along with the planet. Then this speed would have to decrease untill 0 mph because the circumference gets smaller as it flies toward the pole. After flying over the pole the speed would increase again but.. not only that! The direction at which it goes along with the earth actually changes to the opposite after flying over the pole.


The helicopter went from a sideways 1000 mph loop toward a 0 mph pirouette and then changed "sideways" direction after crossing over the pole to then accelerate to 1000 mph again untill it's destination on the other side of the planet. Besides this it went from a 90 degree angle to 0 and back again. For the helicopter "down" is always the center of the earth and regardless of it's own speed, direction and location the earth always seems stationary. Seen from space however it has to make all these movements to stay aligned with the earth.

Objects in motion stay in motion unless acted upon by an outside force. This makes sense to me. What I don't understand is how
the speed relative to the earth gets automatically adjusted. According to Newton's law there has to be some force acting upon the helicopter so it can stay alligned with the earth. If there were no force acting on the helicopter it would keep going sideways at a 1000mph and after just a couple miles toward the pole the allignment would be broken and the helicopter would literally start moving sideways(relative to the earth) as well as forward. I know air friction is not the answer because that would be deadly. Gravity also doesn't answer my question.

So in short:
-How does the speed at which flying machines move along with the earth get automatically adjusted in relation to their position along the meridian?
-How is it possible that we don't feel the change in speed?
-How can a helicopter hover above the pole without seeing the earth beneath it spin? What makes it allign with the earth so the earth seems motionless?

If you've made it this far I thank you for reading. I would love some respectfull answers to these questions burning on my mind. I have believed the earth is spherical all my life but I can't wrap my head around this! In fact I never even thought about it until I heard a believer of the flat earth mention it.

To those who don't understand what I'm asking here I say :

If someone decides to smack u with the end of a broomstick. Would you rather he made the same movement with a stick of 10 cm(0.33 feet) or 100 cm(3.33 feet)?

The earth is a sphere. It spins around its axis. From the axis to the outside of the sphere is the "radius". The radius is longest in the middle of the sphere. From the middle to the top and bottom(poles) the radius gets smaller and smaller. If u measure the sphere in the middle u get the length of the equator. If u measure it at any point at a 90 degree angle to the axis u get the circumference. The radius and circumference are directly related to each other. Because the earth revolves around it's axis once every 24 hours the time is set however the radius and circumference are variables. The longer the circumference the more distance is travelled in these 24 hours and so we get the 1000 mph at the equator of 24000 miles. The closer you get to the poles the smaller the circumference which means that the speed at which u move along with the earth gets lower and lower untill u are at 0mph at the pole.

This whole "More air molecules hit the bottom, and less molecules hit the top" is a really bad way of explaining how an airplane flies. One of the basic assumptions of aerodynamics is the "Continuum Assumption" which basically says that the a fluid (in this case, air) should be treated as a continuous substance, even through it is actually made up of really tiny molecules.
Additionally, whatever momentum that is imparted to the aircraft from the incredibly tiny air molecules hitting the bottom of the surface, would be no where enough to keep the plane aloft.
Lift is generated from pressure differences. Because the lower surface of the wing has a higher pressure than the top (because of accelerating flow) that acts over the area of the wing, a larger force is generated on the bottom of the wing than on the top, resulting in a net upward force. This net upward force is called "Lift".

As one who studied aerospace engineering in college, I couldn't simply sit idly by after viewing this poor explanation of lift.

I like the "wing-ception" thing you did but the way you described HOW a wing produces lift could have been much better. Typical wing design forces air passing over the wing to travel a further distance than air passing under the wing in the same amount of time, therefore making it move faster on the top than on the bottom. With the Bernoulli principle we know that when we increase velocity of a liquid or gas, we also decrease pressure. This is what creates the low pressure on the top of the wing and produces lift. You could have mentioned the equation used to calculate lift, and note that in the equation velocity is squared, making it a huge factor in the lift produced. Double the speed, and you quadruple the lift. That's why airplanes need to change the "coefficient of lift" of their wings to fly at slower speeds by lowering the flaps.

The air doesn't smash into the wing and bounce away like in your animation. If it did, the wing would stall. Look up videos on "laminar flow" vs "turbulent flow" to see. If the air didn't slide smoothly over the surfaces of the wing, it wouldn't be moving faster on the top than on the bottom and the lift would be significantly reduced, replaced by massive amounts of induced drag which the engines thrust would have to overcome. When the flow over the wing becomes "turbulent", the wing stalls and the plane falls like a rock.

I usually love these, but this has been a myth forever. I know all the text books in school talk about Bernoulli, the shape of the wings, lift, etc., but it's all nonsense. A simple counterexample is the fact planes can fly upside down. If the shape of the wings were that important, then that would be impossible (they are important, but for efficiency). It was proven years ago that the Bernoulli Effect is simply not strong enough to keep a jet in the air. Planes stay in the air for one simple reason: Newton's 3rd law. The air washing down over the back of the wings, causes the plane to rise.

I only missed 1 thing, and that is the effect of AoA on the airflow on both sides of the wing. You explained it as airparticles bumping into the wing, which is true to an extent, but because of the AoA the speed of the airflow on the long side of the wing is increased thus creating an underpressure (and the resulting force is lift)
So in one sentence; the angle of attack influences the speed and pressure of the airflow over the wing relative to the speed and pressure under the wing.
However, there is a limit to how far you can do this (maximum angle of attack)
Above AoAmax the airflow over the top gets distorted and "leaves" the wing in a turbulent flow instead of streaming to near the back of the wing, thus losing most of the lift and that is what we call a stall. It is not as if there are alot of airparticles hitting the top of the wing all of a sudden, but the loss the lowpressure airflow over the wing
Force of weight, not force of gravity.

Also, it's important the airplane material: thanks to some materials (the most common is alluminium 2000 and 7000) air molecules can 'touch' the wings and generate the lift, reducing the aerodynamic drag

there are 2 theories on how airplanes fly. (yes they're still just theories, not absolute certainties yet)

the first theory is bernoulli's principle. the upper wing accelerates air faster than the bottom wing, faster velocity=lower pressure, pressure difference causes "lift"

the second theory, which i think is more true, is newton's third law. for ever action there is an equal opposite reaction.

air molecules come into contact with top surface of wing, adheres to the surface, follows the camber (curve) of the wing and is accelerated downwards. the downward acceleration imposes a force equal and opposite, thus pushing the wing up which we call lift.

this theory can be tested by a multitude of ways

The thing that makes aeroplanes fly (apart of money :) ) is the action-reaction. When the airstream at the top of the wing follows the curvature, it is pushed down. The mass of air pushed down has the opposite effect to the wing (pushing it up) due to the above mentioned phenomenon. 
Now, why did I mention stall? Well, if that air at the top just stops following the wing's top curve, then the wing is in stall state. That means that it produces negative lift (pushing down) rather than the positive lift that neutralises gravity. 
When does the airflow not follow the curvature of the wing? well, long story short, when the wing exceeds a specific angle-of-attack then it goes in to stall state. That can happen in high speeds (crazy right?)
Absolutely loved the video Henry! Just now need to explain how gliders fly for hours and hours (and even days) with no thrust from an engine.

Force is the time rate of change of momentum.  Air mass sucked into the propeller leaves with increased momentum to the rear.  The force on that parcel of air is directed into the propeller blade according to Newton's Third Law.  Thus thrust by whatever engine.  The lift is achieved by increasing the momentum of the air in the vertical direction.  This generally requires an angle of attack.  The shape of the airfoil has the primary job of reducing turbulence: Leading edge slots and trailing edge flaps allow for adaptable airfoil shapes and help with turbulence at high angles of attack.

Bernoulli has a law which is very useful  for fluid flow in closed pipes, such as pitot tubes for determining airspeed.  Airfoils moving in unbounded space require much more complicated mathematics than Bernoulli offers.  (See Wikipedia)

The net force on the airplane moving through the air has a vertical component (lift) and a rearward component (drag).  The net lift must equal the weight of the craft, while the thrust from the engines must equal the drag at constant speed.

This is the best explanation I have seen on the internet. I'm glad it keeps away from the ambiguous descriptions which use the Bernoulli effect as this is much misunderstood by a lot of people. It is an intuitive way of describing it. A lot of people are saying that it's the acceleration of the particles over the top of the wing creating less pressure rather than the increased collisions below creating the lift. The thing to realise here is the increased collisions below is an increase in pressure on the wing from below. The particles above accelerate along the wing because of the proportionately lower pressure created above which is in essence Bernoulli's principle, although his principle specifically applies to air in a single streamline so describing it that way has to be taken with a pinch of salt if not explained very rigorously. However I have noticed that people from a non-science or an engineering background describe it in a different way and may well mean the same thing.

lift is to do with Bernoulli principle. the top half of the wing is a convergent duct. bernoulis principle states that if the velocity increases like in a convergent duct then the the velocity increases, pressure drops and temperature drops. this mean the pressure is much lower on the top half of the wing and the pressure higher on the bottom. also there is a run off effect, this is because the wings angle of attack means the airflow shoots of at a slight angle and newtons third law is for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. also lift at supersonic speeds requires shock waves to be generated to slow the airflow. much like supersonic airflow's which generate shock waves at the entrance and use a variety of divergent and convergent ducts to get the airflow to mach 0.5. this video isnt wrong but doesnt really explain it well.

I find the 'pressure' description of the wing somewhat misleading - it focuses people on the 'bernoulli' aspect which is not the main source of lift in a real human-scale aircraft.

Another way of thinking of a wing is as a air pump - it pumps enough air downwards for the reaction force to balance out the weight of the plane. This also helps explain the danger of downwash from a large, heavy plane.

The plane itself is also a lifting body. It's not "just the wings" that keeps it in the air. The whole shape of the airplane creates an lifting force and stabilizes the whole flight. It should also be mentioned that the force produced due to Bernoulli's principle is almost non-existing compared to the force due to the AoA (angle of attack). It is really that force that keeps the plane in the air.

The vacuum generated on the top of a wing is many times the pressure asserted on the bottom of the wing.  Wings are not pushed up, they are sucked up.  Look outside the next time you're in an airliner and see the lovely puckering of the wing skins.  This is not because of the bending the wing is going through, that's the skin of the plane getting sucked off the ribs.  Why this happens gets bantered around and people with scrambled letters after their name constantly go back and forth, taking credit every time as to why it works.  How, is not really an important matter.  What matters is that it is known how to shape an airfoil for the most efficient shape for the job at hand and let the phd's deal with the minutia. 
Prop planes are not thrust forward by their propellers.  Again, correctly identified as wings, they SUCK the plane forward.  While having nothing behind the propeller is ideal you can fairly much block off the area behind a propeller and yet still have propulsion.  This is because the propeller is sucking the air in front of it and pushing it back just anywhere.  Jet engines work differently though the high bypass ducted fans essentially do the same.  Jet aircraft like fighter jets do not work on the suction of air into the engine they work off the expansion of that air by superheating it.  Heating the air increases the volume of it dramatically.  Easy to remember, Props suck what Jets blow.
It is a balancing act.  Lift has to equal weight, thrust equal drag to maintain a static condition of the aircraft.
Airfoils for Civy air are generally optimized for upright flight.  Many can be flown inverted by increasing the angle of attack to a point where the curvature of those airfoils is compensated for.  Aerobatic airplanes tend to have an almost symmetrical but they commonly are optimized for more lift in the upright condition because that is the condition they land in.  Modern Fighter aircraft, airliners and others have variable geometry wings.  You'll see the leading edge of the aircraft move down, the trailing edge of the wing moved out and down increasing the camber of the wing (the curve downward of the wing) AND increasing the area of the wing dramatically as well.  This increases drag greatly but also greatly increases lift allowing the plane to land at a much lower speed.  At higher speeds you don't need that much camber or wing to balance lift and weight, it's a remarkable improvement over fixed shape wings.  If you have a chance to watch F-16's or F-18's (more modern fighters) drop ordinance you'll usually get to see the wing vary geometry as the load is let go of.  The flight computers compensate automatically on these aircraft, both upright and inverted, it's really cool.

But it's not the force on the bottom of the wing that generates the majority of the lift.  A cooler video would be the demonstration of the fact that it's not the vaccum on the top of the wing that makes the plane fly-it's the propulsion of air from above it downward that makes the plane fly.  I know it SOUNDS like a mixture of what I said and what he said but it's just a variation of what I said.  Capture a picture of an airplane flying over a cloud bank and you'll see the downwash of the aircraft in the clouds.  The mass of air is equal to the force needed to hold the plane up.  Proponents of that theory say it isn't the lift on the top of the wing, the pushing from the bottom but the movement of the air only.

Trying to divine which force is the one responsible for the flying of aircraft is again and tug of war between phd's, a glory land of chest beating and hand shaking.  The methods used to modify airfoils and wings for effect remain the same.  Having run wind tunnel tests on many airfoils once factor also remained the same, up to shearing (the loss of flow over the top of the wing) the low pressure on the top of the wing is always more then the pressure on the bottom.  Four to even higher.  Loose that flow (called stalling) and the plane falls out of the air even with the pressure on the bottom of the wing.

So the question of why airplanes can fly upside down is an interesting one, and nobody here has gotten the answer really correct. Certain symmetric airfoils (NACA 000x are known for this) actually do product lift at a zero angle of attack because of the nonzero circulation of air around the wing - this is called the Kutta–Joukowski theorem and is exceedingly complicated, requiring very serious levels of vector calculus. The simple explanation, however, is that the rotation of the air around the wing due to the viscous and geometric effects of the flow actually creates a higher velocity over the side of the wing facing upwards, no matter the orientation of the airfoil.

The full explanation is so complicated that it really isn't even covered in depth until a second Fluid Dynamics / Aerodynamics course, but if you'd like an overview check the wiki page for the Kutta–Joukowski theorem, or look for a PDF of the book Aerodynamics by Anderson.

Think of the air over the wings. The flowrate of air (Q) is constant top and bottom. What isn't is the superficial air velocity. The air on the top of the wing has to travel a longer distance. So to maintain "Q", the velocity of the air on top of the wing is faster than below the wing. Apply Bernoulli's equation and you find that the pressure (P) is higher underneath the wing...thus lift.

Some many years ago I was talking to an engineer/ pilot who insisted that the Bernoulli principle had nothing to do with wing lift. His argument was that some planes can fly upside down, and he further argued that what a wing really did was force a weight of air molecules equal to the weight of the plane downward with enough force to obtain stasis.
In considering this postulation, I began studying those planes that could do that trick flying, as opposed to those that should not ever attempt it. The famous stunt loop done at the unveiling of the 707 prototype comes to mind. As an airliner it was never meant to fly upside down and that loop did not actually do so, as it maintained light positive pressure on the underside of the wing throughout the maneuver the way that rollercoaster loops do to riders. But for stunt and fighter aircraft, true upside down flying can be done, but not very efficiently.
Take a look at one doing it in the next airshow you go to: it will have a much higher angle of attack during that phase. If it goes sideways at a level for a while(wings vertical to earth) the pilot will have put it into a slight climb first, and then the aircraft will be falling as fast as the inertia of the climb can counter that motion, or the fuselage angle of attack combined will allow it to remain level.
Bernoulli lift is more about the subtleties of the recombination of the two flows after the wing has passed through. Good differential wing curvatures can make this a quite efficient(lower drag) process. For the jet airliners this efficiency is optimised for that 10km altitude the video keeps referencing.

The shape of the wings has nothing to do with the lift that is generated. There are actually wing shapes that have a "negative lift" from their shape alone. The reason why airplanes fly is the same reason why helicopters fly and that is the Newtons axiom of "actio est reactio". The force with which the air is pushed downwards is equal, but in opposite direction, of the force which pushes the airplane up. It doesn't matter if there are more molecules beneath the wing, which shape it has and so on, that would be due to Bernoulli's principle, which is far too weak to lift an airplane.
